Name: Hovsa!
Description:
Roll and move game for four players. Each player have five slim pawns in their color. On turn each player rolls a d6 die and move one of their pawn along a spiral of 48 colored spaces. The goal is to reach the center space. The catch is that the board consists of two layers: An upper visible layer with holes, one for each space, for the slim pawns to rest in, and a lower layer with seven holes allowing a pawn to drop out of the game. Before playing, the lower layer is randomly rotated and flipped relative to the visible top layer. The players are only allowed to have two pawns at the board at the same time. A disappeared pawn is out of the game. If a player loses all their pawns the player is eliminated. Thus, players tries to remember the positions of the bottomless pits to avoid losing all pawns.

—user summary

Name: Shitty City Lights Committee
Description:
You work for the council in a small town, and this year have 'volunteered' to organise the town's Christmas decorations. It's important to do a good job, to cheer up the townspeople as we head into winter... but it's more important to ensure that more people turn up to your lights switch-on ceremony than those of other towns around the county - your job could depend upon it!

In Shitty City Lights Committee, 2-4 players take turns to move a marker around a central rondel to select a role that everyone performs, raising funds, buying up decorations and lights, and installing them around town. The catch is that before the rondel selection is made each round the active player rolls some dice, and these are drafted by players to determine the efficacy of their actions - sometimes determining the cost, sometimes the order of play, sometimes the specific pattern they can draw onto their personal town layout.

—description from the designer

Name: Murder Happens: Done In Out Of Prescott Junction
Description:
Murder mystery party game for 8-12 players that you host at home. Each player dresses up as a character, one is the murderer and the rest must figure out who that is. To solve the mystery there are clues, police report, crime scene photos, and a map. You go over these materials then question all the players about what their characters did and saw to finally solve who done it. The game lasts a timed 2.5 hours.

In a bare board town in the Arizona territory a steam engine idles while water from the Prescott Junction tower pours into her tanks. Puffs of steam periodically hiss from her sides. The weary passengers are not happy that the train will be delayed overnight. When they continue on their journey tomorrow though they might wish that they had stayed after all.
In a train headed out west from Chicago are all the western dreams. Starting a new life, striking it rich, and escaping the law. There are your typical conflicts as well, water, money, land, women, fighting, killing, and just general out west rowdiness. It’s a long slow trip and the passengers are restless, so a galloping train robbery might seem like a nice break from the monotony. Boredom leads to other activities too, you probably know what I mean.
This big as the western sky story has just about everything you’d expect in a western, plus some mysterious cursed tunnels, cattle, and murder happens. Which, in the general picture of things, probably isn’t all that surprising.

—description from the publisher

Name: Murder Happens: The Beatnik Who Wasn't Beat, but was Shot
Description:
Murder mystery party game for 8-12 players that you host at home. Each player dresses up as a character, one is the murderer and the rest must figure out who that is. To solve the mystery there are clues, police report, crime scene photos, and a map. You go over these materials then question all the players about what their characters did and saw to finally solve who done it. The game lasts a timed 2.5 hours.

In the medium sized town of Richmond, north of San Francisco, is a flourishing beatnik community. It’s not a big time city but they have gained some notoriety for their poets and artists. Richmond has the typical big city intrigues of politics and the art business. It also has drugs, wild music, orgies, political scandals, anarchists, wild philosophers and even some bikers that are all part of the scene.
Throw into the mix characters with criminal backgrounds, frustrated writers, fake artists and fake beatniks and you have a recipe for the oldest crime known to man.
Get out your bongos, berets, some Jazz, red wine, spaghetti, and garlic bread. Brush up on your beatnik lingo and you will set the mood for this titillating tale of coooool cat intrigue.

—description from the publisher

Name: What? What!
Description:
What? What!, a.k.a. C'est pas faux: Patates & ninjas, is a family version of Think Again, which was released in French as C'est pas faux. The basic idea of the new game is the same as the original, but with a few twists.

One player reads a question to everyone. The answer is on the image on the back of the card. Be the first to answer it correctly. When the reader finishes his question, they roll the die. Your answer must respect what the die asks: a right or a wrong answer. You can give only one answer each time.

The winner takes the question card as a point, draws the next card and is the reader for the next question. The first player to five points wins.

—description from publisher

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition): Orc Team Booster
Description:
Orcs have been playing Blood Bowl since the game was discovered – indeed it was an Orc who discovered the shrine where the sacred book of Nuffle was hidden. Orc teams are very hard-hitting, concentrating on pounding an opponent into the turf to create gaps through which the excellent Orc Blitzers can run. Indeed, if any fault can be found with Orc teams in general, it is that they sometimes spend a little bit too much time pounding the opposition, and not enough time running the ball to score!

Expand your roster and add variation to your line-up with this booster pack! It contains 4 resin miniatures – 1 Blitzer, 1 Thrower and 2 hulking Black Orcs, each covered in detail and posed dynamically, as well as differently to the plastic models from the Blood Bowl boxed game. They're the perfect way to add variety to your Orc Blood Bowl team.

These 4 resin miniatures are supplied with 4 32mm Blood Bowl bases. Up-to-date Orc team rules can be found in the Blood Bowl Almanac 2018.

Key Features
New players for your Orc team
Add variety to your lineup
4 gorgeously detailed miniatures

—description from the publisher

Name: Makiavelia
Description:
Makiavelia is a highly interactive strategy and negotiation card game, in which players vie for power an wealth by accumulating as many coins as possible.

Each round, players will draw cards, build their city or attack other players' cities, using building, army and influence cards. More importantly though, players will negotiate, trade and influence one another. At the end of each round, they will combine their power score to form regimes, and the player or regime with the highest score receives the share of treasure.

But regimes have tensions within and are not forever, those who were once your allies, may just be your enemies next.

Makiavelia combines engine-building, take-that, trade and bluffing into 60 min of unique diplomatic excitement.

—description from the publisher

Name: Rebustory
Description:
Rebustory is a French game in which players must form rebuses (express words or sentences through drawings or signs) with illustrated cards.

Game content:
140 cards including 128 "image" cards, 11 jokers and 1 Rebustory card, 1 card dispenser shoe, an hourglass, a score book and a game rule.

Goal:
Form rebuses and be the first player to reach the 300-point score to be crowned the winner of the game.

Start of the game:
Shuffle the cards and deal 10 cards to each player. The rest of the cards are placed in the shoe, face down.

The 1st player begins:

     He draws a card from the shoe.
     If he can, he places all the cards forming his rebus in front of him, then counts all these points and marks them on the scorebook.
     If he can't form a rebus, he throw a card.


And it is the 2nd player's turn (clockwise), he draws a card from the shoe OR the last card from discard. And so on as the first player.

—user summary

Name: Öresund Svensk: Dansk Ordlek
Description:
Swedish/Danish card game where you learn about words in the other language.

Made for the opening of the Öresundsbron between Sweden and Denmark in 2000.

Plays like Happy Families, but in two different languages.

—user summary

Name: Zauber-Zoff
Description:
Zauber-Zoff is a fantasy card-game best played with 3-4 players, about a kingdom falling apart Each player is playing one scoundrel trying to amass as many riches as possible by winning battles (rounds).
Since most of the 100 cards are unique and have interactions with other cards, each game is very different - and new situations arise every time you play. Since everybody draws from the same pile it might seem that it is more about luck than anything else, but a good player will probably best his mediocre opponents in three out of four games.
So summon Elves, Goblins, Kings, Princes, Ogres and Dragons to loot Rings, Treasure or take the royal family for ransom.
Playing in rounds, you either aim to win a round, just screw things up for the one who does win and/or try to just get as many new cards as possible for a whole gang of critters for you to play in the next.

—description from the designer

Name: MONSTER COMBAT
Description:
Fight friends or fight numerous monsters together? The new card game Monster Combat from Tabletop Heroes leaves this decision to the players, because it can be played in both variants. Two to seven players go into battle together or against each other to fight aggressive monsters.

A player starts, then the game continues clockwise. Each move consists of one to two mandatory phases and an optional phase in a given order. The player's turn is to carry out the following actions:


     Draw a card from the draw pile
     Check event
     Play hand card (optional)


Once a player has completed one, two or all three phases, his turn is over. If he has more than seven cards in his hand at the end of the turn, he must reduce his hand cards by placing his surplus cards on the card tray. The actions of discarded cards are not triggered. It's the next player's turn.

The last one to survive wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Moutown
Description:
Moutown is a family game based on communication between players.
You will need to look at other players and react quickly to win.
Each player owns two sheepfold, each on is shared with one of the neighbor.
You will need to choose quickly the best ships in the pile while taking into account the the choices made by your neighbors.
—user summary

MOU­TOWN est un jeu fami­lial doux et mol­le­tonné qui vous tien­dra chaud l’hi­ver. Toute l’ori­gi­na­lité du jeu réside dans un savant mélange de com­mu­ni­ca­tion entre les joueurs, de rapi­dité et d’ob­ser­va­tion. Rem­plis­sez vos Ber­ge­ries avec les meilleurs mou­tons, avant les joueurs adverses mais pre­nez garde aux Loups !

—description from the publisher

Name: Historia Lublina
Description:
A timeline-like game about one of the Polish cities - Lublin. Players organize cards with historical events that took place in or around the city in chronological order. They can also use one of four special powers that influence played or unplayed cards.

—user summary

Name: The Grimm Forest: Brothers Grimm Promo Card
Description:
The English version of this promo card was available from the Man Vs Meeple Kickstarter campaign in 2018.

Card text:

End of Gather Phase: If you share a location with another player, discard the Brothers Grimm and search the Friend deck for any friend card and put it into play.

Name: Near and Far: Pandoran Box Promo Card
Description:
A promo card given out as part of the Man Vs Meeple 2018 Kickstarter campaign and later from the Promo Paradise 2019 Kickstarter campaign.

Card text:

When you build a camp, roll a die and gain: (1) coin, (2) Gem, (3) -1 rep, (4) green banner, (5-6) -1 heart

Name: Monumental: Lost Kingdoms
Description:
The “Lost Kingdoms” civilization box is the perfect expansion to Monumental with 4 new Civilizations: Aztecs, Mughals, Amazons and Atlanteans (all perfectly compatible with the 5 Core civilizations) as well as more terrain tiles with new environments (desert, jungle, islands, Aztec pyramids) to enable an all-new 5 players mode!

In “Lost Kingdoms” each civilization comes with its own deck of cards including cultural policies, Knowledge and Buildings as well as new very specific Provinces per civilization: pyramids for the Aztecs, desert for The Mughals, jungle for the Amazons and islands for the Atlanteans. Of course, these new terrain could be used with or without the Civilization to enhance the look of the board and your creation of maps.

Altogether with the Core box, 9 Civilizations are now ready to fight for glory and dominance in Monumental against other players or in Solo mode.

Name: Dubai Race
Description:
From the Kickstarter Page:
"The game is an unlimited multi-player board game to build the highest building in Dubai. The winner is the player who has the tallest building at the end of game."

Players first lay out their 10 hexagonal base tiles one by one in Phase I.

In Phase II they place one of their wooden polyominoes onto each base tiles of their color.

In Phase III each player moves one of their polyominoes in a straight line onto another tile, forming a tower. These movements are only legal, if the pieces are set higher than they started their movement.

If a tower tumbles, all the towers belonging to the player are removed from the game, meaning bankruptcy for the player.

The player who own the last tower, wins the game!

Name: Battle of the Twin Villages: Krinkelt-Rocherath
Description:
Battle of the Twin Villages: Krinkelt-Rocherath is a natural follow-on to the successful Hurtgen Forest monster.

The Battle of Elsenborn Ridge was the only sector of the American front lines during the Battle of the Bulge where the Germans failed to advance.[1] The battle centered on the Elsenborn Ridge east of Elsenborn, Belgium in the Ardennes forest. West of Elsenborn Ridge, near the cities of Liège and Spa, Belgium, was a vast array of Allied supplies and the well-developed road network leading to the Meuse River and Antwerp. The Germans planned on using two key rollbahns or routes through the area to seize Antwerp and force a separate peace with the United States and Britain. Capturing Monschau and the nearby village of Höfen, and the twin villages of Rocherath-Krinkelt just east of Elsenborn Ridge, were key to the success of the German plans, and Hitler committed his best armored units and infantry troops to the area, including the 12th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend.

The green, untested troops of the 99th Infantry Division had been placed in the sector during mid-November because the Allies thought it was an area unlikely to see battle. Their soldiers were stretched thin over a 22-mile front, and all three regiments were on line, with no reserve. In early December, the 2nd Infantry Division was assigned to capture a vital crossroads marked by a customs house and a forester’s lodge named Wahlerscheid, at the southern tip of the Battle of Hürtgen Forest. They transitioned through the 99th division's lines and after a deadly, costly battle, capturing the crossroads. But the Germans counterattacked in what the Americans initially thought was a localized spoiling action, but was actually a leading element of the Battle of the Bulge. The 2nd ID consolidated their lines, pulling back into Hünningen, and then to the twin villages of Rocherath-Krinkelt, and finally at the dug-in positions held by the 99th ID at Elsenborn Ridge.

What you get in ATS Battle of the Twin Villages:

ALL the combat counters you need to play
New, large-hex winterized map for the historical battlefield
Color Battlefield Walkaround rules in 3-hole format
Color scenario format, bloody warm red you know the drill!
Monster scenario to tie it all together without all that ordering from a Chinese restaurant menu > they were there, you plop them down and get rolling!
AFV Cards for all the AFVs in the module

—description from the publisher

Name: Nemo's War (Second Edition): Bold and Caring Expansion Pack #2
Description:
The second expansion pack for Nemo's War, Bold and Caring, features two new motives for Captain Nemo: Adventure and Humanist! As experienced players know, each motive is like playing a different game!

Answering the call to adventure, each Lull Turn provides 2 Actions and places one of the new Adventure tokens in the just-rolled “doubles” Ocean. When the Nautilus performs a successful Search Action at that Ocean, you reveal and place its Adventure token. You can then go questing for that adventure and try to earn the big rewards it offers.

With the Adventure motive, you can also commence play with a new Nautilus Upgrade card: Diving Apparatus which assists you with all Test rolls for which you spend 2 Actions and helps keeps the Adventure Deck stocked with gemstones.

The Humanist motive sees Captain Nemo desiring to better the plight of the common people. Potentially starting with the Hospital Machines Upgrade card, it allows the Captain to parley with ships at sea using “Diplomacy Attacks.”

Although Notoriety gains are a big problem, successful diplomacy allows you three courses of action: Further Diplomatic Relations, Create a Diplomatic Incident, or Gather Support for Your Good Intentions. Incitement cubes become “Goodwill cubes," and the more nations that you parley with, the higher bonus score you can earn!

Components:

• 2 Nautilus Upgrade Cards (Diving Apparatus and Hospital Machines)
• 1 New Motive Tile: Adventure / Humanist
• 4 New Treasure Tokens
• 1 Diplomatic Attack Token
• 9 Adventure Tokens
• 1 Rules Sheet

NOTE: You must own a copy of Nemo's War Second Edition to enjoy this Expansion Pack.

Name: Nemo's War (Second Edition): Dramatis Personae Expansion Pack #3
Description:
The third expansion pack, Dramatis Personae, provides your game with a neat stack of ten additional cards: nine new Adventure cards and one intriguing new Finale card.

Among the new adventures, you will learn more about your familiar crew characters, and meet interesting new characters via five new Keep cards, allowing them to assist you with their talents. Balancing out the benefits of these helpful cards are new Play and Test Adventure cards that will keep you riveted.

Components:

• 9 New Adventure Cards
• 1 New Finale Card
• 1 Rules Sheet

NOTE: You must own a copy of Nemo's War Second Edition to enjoy this Expansion Pack.

Name: Of Dreams & Shadows: Potion of Courage Promo Card
Description:
This is a promo card for Of Dreams & Shadows.

"Potion of Courage " is a new resource card that you add to the resource deck at the beginning of the game.

It is am "Item," with a cost of 2, and the following ability: "Discard this card to regain two."

This promo was released in Game Trade Magazine #224 (October 2018).

Name: Mythos Tales: Auf Ewig
Description:
December 23, 1928
A fire was set at the Arkham University Library and a Book with delicate content stolen.

This additional Case for Mythos Tales was created by the German Publisher Pegasus Spiele to demonstrate the System at the Spiel18 in Essen, without to spoil the actual content of the Base game. It was later available for a limited time from December 7 to 9, 2018 as a free print and play version.

Name: Harem Wars: Harem Combat
Description:
This expansion adds an additional 120 cards to the game, a set of special Harem dice, a new game mat AND a set of instructions on a new way to play the game. The game mode will allow you to also play alone making the game for 1-4 players.

—description from the publisher

Name: Rachmistrz
Description: Rachmistrz (Reckoner) is a lightweight math game with a real-time twist. During a turn 3 dice with numbers are rolled and players start to calculate their best move! All players use addition, subtraction, multiplication and division to reach one of numbers available on the main board. They place their tokens on the result of their operations. They have to be fast as once covered, numbers on the board become unavailable for the rest of the game! At the end of the game, the player with most connected tokens is declared the winner. Once you have mastered the regular board with whole numbers try the flip side of the board presenting you with fractions!

Name: [microfilms]: The Honeymooners Promo
Description:
Promo card that was given for free as part of the Pocket Dragon Kickstarter-campaign.

Setup: Place this card in the middle of the table, within all players’ reach.

Gameplay: During their turn, any player may pay 1 franc to draw a card from the top of the draw deck. This is NOT an action and can only be done once per turn, but cannot be done after discarding down to the hand limit. Place the spent coin on the Honeymooners card. (Thematically, they’re running a con, and handing out cards for money.) When any player takes a Steal action they can choose: steal 2 francs from any other player (as before), OR steal all francs from the Honeymooners. There is nothing more satisfying than conning the con artists after all…

Name: Pitch and Yaw
Description:
Pitch and Yaw is a tabletop miniatures skirmish game, requiring around 6-16 models representing a high seas boarding action in the golden age of piracy. It is a free to download PDF with an extended edition available on our website. 
The game is highly asymmetrical with each player taking turns playing as attacker and defender. The attacker must search the ship before the defender can take too much toll on their forces. Unlike many pirate based skirmish games Pitch and Yaw features a highly dynamic environment representing the difficulty of fighting on a constantly shifting deck. After each round of activating models to move and attack the ship and all unsecured objects will shift.

Name: Villagers: Kickstarter Expansion Pack
Description:
A set of four modular expansions and a wooden start player token for Villagers, included with the Kickstarter edition of the game.

"Scoundrels" adds 9 new villagers.

"Saints" adds 5 new villagers.

"Profiteers" adds 8 new villagers and a new scoring mechanism.

"Developments" adds building 12 cards and 3 colour printed wooden tokens which add an extra scoring opportunity to the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Double-seven binary-coding Hexdominoes
Description:
Double-seven binary-coding hexdominoes is a dominoes-like set that includes 36 tiles (with numbers from 0 to 7) composed of two adjacent hexagons. Instead of the standard ‘pips’, this set uses a special concentric binary representation. A central pip equals 1, a small circle equals 2 and a big circle equals 4. This set is the brother of the double-seven binary-coding dominoes set by the same publisher.

The tiles are made of 8mm thick laser-cut, engraved and painted black acrylic.

It's been devised as a game system. Apart from any dominoes game, you can also play Hexdominimum, Hexdominomega, Hexdominup and Hextra, among others.

—description from the publisher

Name: The Perfect Moment: Las Vegas Gone Wrong
Description: The Perfect Moment: Las Vegas Gone Wrong (2019) is a six-card expansion for The Perfect Moment series that replaces one of the three base sets for a very different playing experience.

Name: L'osti d'jeu 2
Description:
Same thing as L'osti d'jeu, but with 406 new cards (150 black +256 red). It also include 80 blank card so you can make your own extension! Now with black card with double |...| and with asked references of movie, series and other Québec reference!

—description from the publisher (translated)

Le même jeu, mais avec 406 nouvelles cartes (150 noires + 256 rouges) + 80 cartes vierges pour créer ta propre extension! Ça inclut des cartes noires doubles |…| |…|, un plus grand ratio de cartes noires et plein de références québécoises, de télé & films que vous nous avez demandé.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fireball Island: The Curse of Vul-Kar – Secret Cabal Promo Card
Description:
Promo cards:

Secret Cabal - "I am not poisoned by snakes."

Name: 弱者の剣 (Jakusha no Tsurugi)
Description:
å¼±è€…ã®å‰£ (Jakusha no Tsurugi, "Sword of the Weak") is the first game from Polygonotes. It resembles the classic card game Daifugo but adds many twists.

At the start of a round each player is dealt six normal cards and one Sword of the Weak card. Normal cards have two numbers on them, one blue and one red, that always add up to nine, as well as a colored symbol in the middle. The Sword of the Weak has a different pattern on the back and its red and blue numbers are both one.

Your goal is to play all your cards. Each turn you have to either pass (and draw a card) or play cards to the middle. In order to play cards to the middle you have to have a higher total than the previous hand, and whether you use the red or blue numbers depends on the Scales card by the deck - it starts on blue, but every time a Sword of the Weak is played it's flipped. Being lucky will help you play larger hands, but in order to win you'll have to correctly time when you play your Sword card for the greatest advantage.

—user summary

Name: 逆臣の炎 (Gyakushin no Honoo)
Description:
é€†è‡£ã®ç‚Ž (Gyakushin no Honoo, "Fire of  the Rebel") is the second game from Polygonotes. You play as a servant in the house of a mad king, waiting for a chance to depose him to save the kingdom.

The game has three special kinds of cards. There's one each of the Night and the Dawn, which move around the table - the Night is always held by the active player, and the Dawn by the previous player. In the deck there are many "Flames of the Treacherous Retainer" cards, which have different colored backs. A round ends when one player has three Flames and the Night card; you win by having 20 points at the end of a round.

Each turn you can play a card or draw a card. Some cards can't be played and just add points (positive or negative) to your hand. Others have all kinds of effects, like making another player put a Flame on the bottom of the deck, reversing turn order, or even flipping the deck upside down. Even the Night and Dawn cards are worth points, so you might want to trick someone else into ending the hand.

In order to win you'll have to choose when to play your cards right as well as bluff the other players as to how good your hand is. Can you depose the king?

—user summary

Name: Don't Lose Your Cool
Description: Inspired by the internet's viral challenges that have gathered billions of views, Don't Lose Your Cool tests one's ability to remain calm under pressure. Players wear the Cool-O-Meter that measures their heart rate, and the opposing team rolls the dice that determine how they'll try to get the player to get flustered. A change in heart rate effects the meter and when the meter gets high enough the lights get to red, the alarm sounds, and the opponent wins for making that player lose their composure.

Name: Chow Crown
Description:
Who will reign supreme in the ultimate snack eating competition? Chow Crown puts a fun twist on viral food-eating challenges! To play, load the six hanging forks with various food items of your choosing. Place the spinning crown on your head, and eat as many snacks as possible before the music stops to keep your crown!

Chow Crown can be played solo or in a head-to-head tournament. The game includes the electronic crown, six plastic forks, and instructions. Requires 3 AA batteries, not included. Food not included.

Name: Awkward Hugs
Description:
Awkward Hugs is the game of connections, questions, and consequences! Two players are locked in a hug by the included hug belts, and another player asks questions like, "Would you swim with sharks?" or "Are you a binge watcher?" Both huggers must answer the same way or they'll get a hilarious consequence card such as slow dancing or standing like a flamingo. Match three questions correctly to unlock the hug.

Game includes two hug belts, two keys, a deck of questions cards, a deck of consequences cards, and a game guide.

Name: 信濃国土豪衆 (Shinanokoku Dogoushu)
Description:
ä¿¡æ¿ƒå›½åœŸè±ªè¡† (Shinanokoku Dogoushu, "Lords of Shinano") is a card-laying game about exploring mountainous terrain and choosing the right spot to build a castle.

Each turn you may move and add a card to the map. You can move one step across normal terrain, pay two points to move through mountains, or you can move as far as you want along a river for free. When you add a card it has to be on a space next to your pawn and any rivers must line up. You get points equal to the number on the card (1, 2, or 3, with higher point cards being more complicated) for every edge that perfectly matches what you put it against. If no edges match you can still play the card but it's worth negative points equal to its face value. If you can't play a card at all, you have to discard one face down, which is worth triple negative points at the end of the game.

Once during the game you must play a castle. This costs ten points, but at the end of the game you get points for the card under your castle and the four neighboring cards. Castles must be built at least two cards apart, so building in the right place can also deny other players points. When moving, castles and pawns both allow you charge tolls for anyone passing through, which is the best way to get a point advantage over other players.

Explore the countryside, build your castle in the right place, and see if you can become the richest Lord of Shinano.

—user summary

Name: Pie Face Cannon!
Description:
Have a "blast" and take aim as players "pie" their opponent with a cannon full of whipped cream! To start Pie Face Cannon!, one player steps up and places their face in the facemask, while the other player aims the cannon and tries to launch whipped cream onto their opponent's face. The player behind the mask can try to avoid getting "pie-faced" by using the included blocking hand. Players can earn points by either blocking themselves or by successfully "pie-ing" their opponent. The first player to score five points wins.

Whipped cream not included.

Name: Speech Breaker
Description: Can you overcome the voice-jamming challenge in Speech Breaker? You're reporting live from the scene! Put on the game headset, talk into the game microphone, and get your teammates to guess who/what/where without saying any of the words on the cards. What's the catch? The microphone jams your speech with a built-in delay. As you talk, you hear your delayed voice through the game headset, making it harder to speak clearly. For example, how would you report that "an alien is swinging kettlebells in a glass house" without saying any of those words — and in just 30 seconds — with your speech jammed?

Name: Ryuuki no Toga
Description:
ç«œå§«ã®å’Ž (Ryuuki no Toga, "The Sin of the Dragon Princess") is a push-your luck engine building game. There are only five days left before the final battle - can you defeat the enemy and become a legendary hero?

Long ago the Dragon Princess broke a taboo and had a child with a human. The "Sin" was a target for all the monsters in the world, and to defend her child the Dragon Princes descended into the Abyss. After an unimaginably long time, the Abyss transformed the Dragon Princess into a monster, and she's coming to reclaim her child and destroy the world in the bargain. You have just five days to defeat her.

Each round has three phases: card acquisition, playing units, and deciding whether to challenge the monster. A number of cards equal to the numbers of players is dealt face-up, and everyone reveals which one they want at the same time. If there are any conflicts, the start player for the round decides how to resolve that, and it doesn't have to be fair. Next you play units that add to your battle strength. Some units can be played for free, but advanced units will require spending mana of right color from weaker units. Finally you decide if you're ready to challenge the monster. You only get to do this once, so you want to wait until you're strong enough, but not so long someone else beats the monster first.

—user summary
